Name: Name
The amount of money held by the company: The amount of money held by the company in the form of cash.
The amount of money owed to the company: The amount of money owed to the company by customers who have not yet paid for goods or services received.
The amount of money owed by the company: The amount of money owed by the company to suppliers for goods or services received.
The amount of money owed to the governme: The amount of money owed to the government for sales tax collected from customers.
The amount of money invested by the owne: The amount of money invested by the owner(s) or shareholders to start or expand the business.
The amount of money withdrawn by the own: The amount of money withdrawn by the owner(s) or shareholders from the business for personal use.
Owner's equity is what remains after you: Owner's equity is what remains after you subtract business liabilities from business assets. In other words, it's what's left over for you if you sell all your assets and pay all your debts.
The amount of money earned from selling: The amount of money earned from selling physical or digital products.
The amount of money received from invest: The amount of money received from investments in shares of other companies.
The amount of money earned from interest: The amount of money earned from interest-bearing investments like bonds, certificates of deposit, or savings accounts.
The amount of money earned from foreign: The amount of money earned from foreign exchange transactions due to favorable exchange rate changes.
The amount of money returned to customer: The amount of money returned to customers or deducted from sales due to returned goods or allowances granted.
The amount of money deducted from sales: The amount of money deducted from sales due to discounts offered to customers for early payment or other reasons.
Revenue from other business operations t: Revenue from other business operations that don't fall under regular sales or services. This account is used as the default for all new transactions.
The amount of money paid to employees fo: The amount of money paid to employees for their work, including regular salaries and hourly wages.
The amount of money paid by the employer: The amount of money paid by the employer for payroll taxes and contributions, such as social security, unemployment, and workers' compensation.
The amount of money spent on employee be: The amount of money spent on employee benefits, such as health insurance, retirement plans, and other benefits.
The amount of money paid to third-party: The amount of money paid to third-party payroll processors for payroll services.
The amount of money paid for renting or: The amount of money paid for renting or leasing business premises.
The amount of money paid for taxes on bu: The amount of money paid for taxes on business property.
The amount of money spent on maintaining: The amount of money spent on maintaining business premises, including repairs and cleaning.
The amount of money paid for business ut: The amount of money paid for business utilities, such as electricity, water, and gas.
The amount of money paid for insurance o: The amount of money paid for insurance on business property.
The amount of money spent on food and dr: The amount of money spent on food and drink for business purposes, such as office snacks, meals, and catering.
The amount of money spent on business tr: The amount of money spent on business transportation, such as fuel, vehicle maintenance, and public transportation.
The amount of money spent on business travel, such as airfare, hotels, and rental cars.
The amount of money spent on business en: The amount of money spent on business entertainment, such as client dinners, events, and tickets.
The amount of money spent on office supp: The amount of money spent on office supplies, such as paper, ink, and stationery.
The amount of money spent on office equi: The amount of money spent on office equipment and furniture, such as computers, printers, and desks.
The amount of money paid for legal and p: The amount of money paid for legal and professional services, such as legal advice, accounting, and consulting.
The amount of money spent on software an: The amount of money spent on software and subscriptions, such as SaaS products, cloud services, and digital tools.
The amount of money spent on advertising: The amount of money spent on advertising campaigns, including print, digital, and outdoor advertising.
The amount of money spent on marketing a: The amount of money spent on marketing activities, such as content creation, social media, and email marketing.
The amount of money lost from foreign ex: The amount of money lost from foreign exchange transactions due to unfavorable exchange rate changes.
The amount of money returned to supplier: The amount of money returned to suppliers or deducted from purchases due to returned goods or allowances granted.
The amount of money deducted from purcha: The amount of money deducted from purchases due to discounts offered by suppliers for early payment or other reasons.
Expenses not classified into regular exp: Expenses not classified into regular expense categories. This account is used as the default for all new transactions.
The most liquid assets a company holds. This includes physical currency, bank balances, and short-term investments a company can quickly convert to cash.
Amounts owed to the company for goods so: Amounts owed to the company for goods sold or services rendered, including accounts receivable, notes receivable, and other receivables.
The raw materials, work-in-progress good: The raw materials, work-in-progress goods and completely finished goods that are considered to be the portion of a business's assets that are ready or will be ready for sale.
Payments made in advance for future good: Payments made in advance for future goods or services, such as insurance premiums, rent, and prepaid taxes.
Other assets that are expected to be con: Other assets that are expected to be converted to cash, sold, or consumed within one year or the business's operating cycle.
Investments in securities like bonds and: Investments in securities like bonds and stocks, investments in other companies, or real estate held for more than one year, aiming for long-term benefits.
Physical, tangible assets used in the bu: Physical, tangible assets used in the business's operations with a useful life exceeding one year, such as buildings, machinery, and vehicles. These assets are subject to depreciation.
Assets lacking physical substance but of: Assets lacking physical substance but offering value to the business, like patents, copyrights, trademarks, software, and goodwill.
Includes long-term assets not classified: Includes long-term assets not classified in the above categories, such as long-term prepaid expenses, deferred tax assets, and loans made to other entities that are not expected to be settled within the next year.
Accounts that accumulate depreciation of: Accounts that accumulate depreciation of tangible assets and amortization of intangible assets, reflecting the reduction in value over time.
Accounts representing estimated uncollec: Accounts representing estimated uncollected receivables, used to adjust the value of gross receivables to a realistic collectible amount.
Accounts used to record adjustments in a: Accounts used to record adjustments in asset values due to impairments, market changes, or other factors affecting their recoverable amount.
Funds provided by owners or shareholders: Funds provided by owners or shareholders for starting the business and subsequent capital injections. Reflects the financial commitment of the owner(s) or shareholders to the business.
Cumulative profits retained in the busin: Cumulative profits retained in the business and not distributed as dividends. Indicates the company's financial health and profit-generating ability.
Equity that is deducted from gross equit: Equity that is deducted from gross equity to arrive at net equity. This includes treasury stock, which is stock that has been repurchased by the company.
Liabilities arising from purchases of go: Liabilities arising from purchases of goods or services from suppliers, not yet paid for. This can include individual accounts payable and trade credits.
Expenses that have been incurred but not: Expenses that have been incurred but not yet paid, including wages, utilities, interest, and taxes. This category can house various accrued expense accounts.
Debt obligations due within the next yea: Debt obligations due within the next year, such as bank loans, lines of credit, and short-term notes. This category can cover multiple short-term debt accounts.
Funds received in advance for goods or s: Funds received in advance for goods or services to be provided in the future, including customer deposits and prepayments.
A grouping for miscellaneous short-term: A grouping for miscellaneous short-term liabilities not covered in other categories, like the current portion of long-term debts, short-term provisions, and other similar obligations.
Obligations such as bonds, mortgages, an: Obligations such as bonds, mortgages, and loans with a maturity of more than one year, covering various types of long-term debt instruments.
Taxes incurred in the current period but: Taxes incurred in the current period but payable in a future period, typically due to differences in accounting methods between tax reporting and financial reporting.
Liabilities not due within the next year: Liabilities not due within the next year and not classified as long-term debt or deferred taxes, including pension liabilities, lease obligations, and long-term provisions.
Accumulated amount representing the redu: Accumulated amount representing the reduction of bond or loan liabilities, reflecting the difference between the face value and the discounted issuance price over time.
Adjustments made to the recorded value o: Adjustments made to the recorded value of liabilities, such as changes in fair value of derivative liabilities or adjustments for hedging activities.
Income from selling physical or digital: Income from selling physical or digital products. Includes revenue from all product lines or categories.
Income earned from providing services, e: Income earned from providing services, encompassing activities like consulting, maintenance, and repair services.
Income from other business operations no: Income from other business operations not classified as product sales or services, such as rental income, royalties, or income from licensing agreements.
Earnings from investments, including div: Earnings from investments, including dividends, interest from securities, and profits from real estate investments.
Profits from selling assets like propert: Profits from selling assets like property, equipment, or investments, excluding regular sales of inventory.
Income from sources not related to the m: Income from sources not related to the main business activities, such as legal settlements, insurance recoveries, or gains from foreign exchange transactions.
Revenue that is deducted from gross reve: Revenue that is deducted from gross revenue to arrive at net revenue. This includes sales discounts, returns, and allowances.
Revenue that has not been categorized in: Revenue that has not been categorized into other revenue categories.
Direct costs attributable to the product: Direct costs attributable to the production of goods sold by a company. This includes material costs and direct labor.
Expenses related to employee compensatio: Expenses related to employee compensation, including salaries, wages, bonuses, commissions, and payroll taxes.
Costs incurred for business premises, in: Costs incurred for business premises, including rent or lease payments, property taxes, utilities, and building maintenance.
Expenses related to general business ope: Expenses related to general business operations, such as office supplies, insurance, and professional fees.
Expenses related to marketing and advert: Expenses related to marketing and advertising activities, such as advertising campaigns, promotional events, and marketing materials.
Expenses incurred in the process of rese: Expenses incurred in the process of researching and developing new products or services.
Miscellaneous expenses not categorized e: Miscellaneous expenses not categorized elsewhere, such as research and development costs, legal fees, and other irregular expenses.
Expenses related to borrowing and financ: Expenses related to borrowing and financing, such as interest payments on loans, bonds, and credit lines.
Various taxes incurred by the business,: Various taxes incurred by the business, including income tax, sales tax, property tax, and payroll tax.
Expenses not related to primary business: Expenses not related to primary business activities, like losses from asset disposals, legal settlements, restructuring costs, or foreign exchange losses.
Expenses that are deducted from gross ex: Expenses that are deducted from gross expenses to arrive at net expenses. This includes purchase discounts, returns, and allowances.
Expenses that have not been categorized: Expenses that have not been categorized into other expense categories.
Key financial statements that provide a: Key financial statements that provide a snapshot of your company’s financial health.
Tracks revenue and expenses to show prof: Tracks revenue and expenses to show profit or loss over a specific period of time.
Snapshot of assets, liabilities, and equ: Snapshot of assets, liabilities, and equity at a specific point in time.
Shows cash inflows and outflows over a s: Shows cash inflows and outflows over a specific period of time.
Dig into the details of your company’s t: Dig into the details of your company’s transactions, balances, and accounts.
Summary view of balances and activity fo: Summary view of balances and activity for all accounts.
The sum of all debit and credit balances: The sum of all debit and credit balances for all accounts on a single day. This helps to ensure that the books are in balance.
A record of all transactions for a compa: A record of all transactions for a company. The general ledger is the core of a company's financial records.
